results.abstract: Christmas catalogue from Sakowitz Co dept store in Houston, Texas, offers as 'ultimate gifts' lessons from 16 experts in their field; illus (S)
results.snippet: For $650,000 this Christmas you can learn the secrets of oddsmaking and gambling from Jimmy (the Greek) Snyder, the Las Vegas oddsmaker whose betting lines appear in over 200 American newspapers.
results.lead_paragraph: For $650,000 this Christmas you can learn the secrets of oddsmaking and gambling from Jimmy (the Greek) Snyder, the Las Vegas oddsmaker whose betting lines appear in over 200 American newspapers.

results.abstract: Conservationists fighting resumption of oil drilling along Calif coast urge large-scale manufacture of methanol, which they contend would provide plentiful, cleaner-burning and higher-mileage motor fuel; hold that methanol can be added to regular gasoline, making up 15-30% of resulting fuel, and thus free US of need to import oil; Charles L Stone, who heads methanol study for Calif legis, and Scripps Inst dir Dr William Nierenberg comment; Dr Jeffrey Frautschy of Scripps disputes oil indus contention that methanol will lower mileage and corrode engines; Continental Oil, which has large coal reserves that could be used to make methanol, may join feasibility study, led by nonprofit concern called Edict, which is headed by former astronaut Scott Carpenter; Calif Assemblymen William Greene and Lawrence Kapiloff sponsor bill calling for state to build pilot methanol plant and to require its fuel use in state owned vehicles; experiments with methanol conducted by T B Reed and R M Lerner of MIT and by San Diego Post Office and Univ of Santa Clara noted (M)

headline.main: NEW MOTOR FUEL PUSHED ON COAST; Public Hearing Oil Companies Scored Used by Post Office Denial by Federal Aide Conservationists Advocating Use of Methanol in Gas

headline.main: SovietAstronauts Orbitedin TestforProject With U.S.; New Docking Mechanism Not the First Test

results.snippet: The Soviet Union launched today an improved Soyuz spacecraft with two veteran astronauts aboard into orbit around the earth in a major systems test for the Soviet-American space rendezvous scheduled for next July.

results.lead_paragraph: The Soviet Union launched today an improved Soyuz spacecraft with two veteran astronauts aboard into orbit around the earth in a major systems test for the Soviet-American space rendezvous scheduled for next July.

headline.main: A Political Convention, Sort of; The King Making

results.snippet: Robert Frost once said that writing free verse was like playing tennis Without a net. The Democrats are proving here that much the same can be said for a political convention that is not trying to pick a candidate.

byline.original: Special to The New York TimesBy DOUGLAS E. KNEELAND

results.lead_paragraph: Robert Frost once said that writing free verse was like playing tennis Without a net. The Democrats are proving here that much the same can be said for a political convention that is not trying to pick a candidate.

headline.main: U. S. WON'T DELAY ON SPACE MISSION; NASA Plans to Go Ahead if Soviet Effort Fails Will Go It Alone No Factory Visit

results.snippet: Even if Soviet scientists fail to orbit their Soyuz spacecraft next summer for a rendezvous with a three-men American team for a joint mission, the United States plans to go ahead with an alternate mission of its own.

byline.original: Special to The New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Even if Soviet scientists fail to orbit their Soyuz spacecraft next summer for a rendezvous with a three-men American team for a joint mission, the United States plans to go ahead with an alternate mission of its own.

headline.main: Russian Astronauts Ready For an Apollo Rendezvous

results.snippet: The Soyuz 16 astronauts said today that their six-day flight went without a hitch and pronounced their improved spacecraft ready to rendezvous with' an American Apollo.
results.lead_paragraph: The Soyuz 16 astronauts said today that their six-day flight went without a hitch and pronounced their improved spacecraft ready to rendezvous with' an American Apollo.

results.snippet: Criticizing what he termed "the hodgepodge of bank regulation as it has evolved in this country, John E. Sheehan, a member of the Federal Reserve Board, yesterday supported the idea of a single Federal banking regula tory agency.
results.lead_paragraph: Criticizing what he termed "the hodgepodge of bank regulation as it has evolved in this country, John E. Sheehan, a member of the Federal Reserve Board, yesterday supported the idea of a single Federal banking regula tory agency.

headline.main: I Want to Know About a Flight To the Moon; By Col. Alfred M. Worden. 64 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $4.50. (Ages 8 to 11)

results.snippet: A certain young man I know, age 4 1/2 or thereabouts, chats matter-of-factly about "astronaut Al Wordern" the way he discusses his schoolmates, or his favorite books. His familiarity stems from having met astronaut Al--Col. Alfred M. Worden--on...
results.lead_paragraph: A certain young man I know, age 4 1/2 or thereabouts, chats matter-of-factly about "astronaut Al Wordern" the way he discusses his schoolmates, or his favorite books. His familiarity stems from having met astronaut Al--Col. Alfred M. Worden--on public TV's "Mister Rogers' Neighborhood."

results.abstract: Prof Amitai Etzioni article on Frederick Wiseman documentary film 'Primate,' presented on PBS-TV on Dec 5; notes that filmhas 'raised storm of controversy' because Wiseman shows experiments being conducted with gorillas, chimpanzees and monkeys; analyzes film and asserts that controversy is result of Wiseman's 'editorializing use' of his camera; illus (L)
results.snippet: "Primate," a new film for television by Frederick Wiseman, has raised a storm of controversy. The film deals with the work being conducted at the Yerkes Primate Research Center at Emory University in Atlanta, and it shows a number of laboratory...
results.lead_paragraph: "Primate," a new film for television by Frederick Wiseman, has raised a storm of controversy. The film deals with the work being conducted at the Yerkes Primate Research Center at Emory University in Atlanta, and it shows a number of laboratory experiments with gorillas, chimpanzees and monkeys, including some involving surgery and decapitation.
